moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e6: I am playing the Queen's Indian Defense.
moves.3. Bf4 b6 4. e3 Bb7 5. Nf3 Bb4: Removing this defender because I want to control d5 and e4 in particular.
moves.6. g3: Preparing to fianchetto, but white has also greatly restricted the maneuverability of his DSB.
moves.6... Bxc3+ 7. bxc3: And we have doubled pawns as well. So far so good for me.
moves.7... Ne4: Centralizing the knight, aiming at c3 to capture the weak pawn. I wanted to be aggressive though my development is incomplete.
moves.8. Qd3 Nxc3: Taking the pawn because I have just discovered an attack against white's knight, which has no defender.
moves.9. Qxc3 Bxf3: And forcing the rook to move, meaning that white can't castle kingside. And for the moment, he can't castle queenside and most likely wouldn't want to anyway.
moves.11. Bg2 Bxg2 12. Rxg2 O-O 13. Qd3 d6: Restricting the bishop and preparing a pawn break on e5.
moves.14. Ke2 h6: Further limiting the bishop, though I didn't foresee that trapping it meant that this h pawn would become the target for white to get compensation for the loss.
moves.15. c3: Still, white didn't seem to see what was happening. Instead, he solidified his center.
moves.16. Bxh6 gxh6: But now, I have little protection. This is a problem.
moves.17. Qe4 Qd7: Cutting off the white queen's options (Qg4, namely), and protecting my knight at the same time.
moves.18. Qh4 Kh7: I feel horribly exposed at this point.
moves.19. g4 exd4: Trying for counterplay. This move also opens a spot for my knight that will be important, and also opens the e-file for my rook.
moves.21. Rag1: Building the attack and the push of the pawn, specifically.
moves.21... Qxa2+: And I decided to make a bold decision to disrupt white's initiative, the drawback being that I don't have the tempo to spend on better defense of my position. However, I thought it might be possible that attacking would generate more chances to change the flow of the game...little did I know how much that would be true!
moves.22. Kf3 Qd5+:
Not even really looking ahead right now, just pushing white and attacking. Sometimes, the psychology of the game is important, and I wanted to disrupt white as much as I could.
Another consideration is Ne5+, which I actually played next. I do like this queen move, though.
moves.23. e4 Ne5+: This move was great for multiple reasons. It continues the attack, but also adds a defender of g6 to halt the advance of the pawn.
moves.24. Ke2: In hindsight, it might have been better for white to have done a different move that wouldn't have landed him in another check right away, even if it was Kg3.
moves.24... Qc4+: Now this attack is actually looking real. The white king doesn't really have a safe spot to go, it seems.
moves.25. Kd2: Here I could have forked the king and queen, and I didn't even see it!! However, it ended up not mattering much. Suddenly, the tides are drastically turning on white.
moves.25... Qxc3+ 26. Ke2: One of two places to move. I don't know which would have been better.
moves.26... Qd3+: I was proud of this move, because now the white king has only one spot to go, and at this point I had foreseen the ...Nf3, which I thought would just land me the queen. I didn't look comprehensively enough to realize that...
moves.27... Nf3#: ...It's also checkmate!! A sequence of 7 checks leads to a checkmate that also happens to be a 4-way fork. This doesn't happen every day. It's beautiful, though I sympathize with white, who definitely had the initiative until this crazy sequence unfolded.

gameName: The Most Welcome Win is the Most Unforseen?
